content.text: Standing on two feet is the stage that for the first time the baby needs to deal with gravity on a small base (2 legs) not like in the former milestones where the base was wide.
Standing is based on all the former milestones that the infant experiences. There are two ways to stand correctly:

ol: From kneeling , coming up foot by foot to standing.
From squatting with both legs and stand up without any help.

content.text: Preparing the body for walking by using the balance ability of small base - standing on two feet instead of crawling (6 points of contact with the surface) or seating (both arms and legs) that they are a wide base.
Learning to carry the weight of the body on 2 feet and balance between the upper and lower body.

If you are seeing that your baby has a hard time achieving the specific milestones described in the description or are at the age of 11 months and canâ€™t do those things you should consult with your pediatrician or an Infant development guide in order to learn how to help your baby to achieve these important abilities that are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs:

ul: Unable to transfer from standing to sitting by himself and supported by something, without falling
The space between two legs is too wide (more than the pelvic wide)
The knees are locked (looks like a bear walking on two legs)
Feet are turning in or out instead of straight (Club Foot)
Standing with his back bending forward
The shoulders are higher than they should be
Standing on tiptoes most of the time
